review_title: Good practice if you need to get out of your comfort zone
pros: Training is now better than when I began (focus on investments, managed money) and verbiage that is done regionally and online instead of being lost in the weeds at a firm level. Great practice cold calling and talking to orphaned clients but they have been talked to many times before. Some benefits can be good if you stay long enough and grind it out.
cons:
Manager and experienced advisors alienated my client base, family, friends. Manager put too much emphasis on going after family money with new hires than actually developing those already full-time (self-serving, egocentric compensation is valued well above the best interest of advisors and their clientele) . Misogynistic 'frat house' atmosphere than professional environment. Promised guidance and veteran help but found more success grinding it out on my own.
Advice to Management
Is committing to no more than ten percent of your promises industry standard? Lots of opportunity to truly serve your advisors and in the absolute best interest of their clientele.

pros: I felt my manager cared about me to a degree, and my coworkers were very supportive. Generally, the job consists of reaching out to your network or calling out to "orphaned" leads who are current Prudential clients not aligned to a financial professional and pitching new business opportunities. I always had unaligned leads to contact, but I'm not sure if that is still the policy.
cons:
Health benefits don't start until you hit a certain amount of production. Also, you don't get access to the unaligned leads until you hit that same threshold of production. The motivation is to incentive new employees to ask senior financial professionals for their unaligned leads and to do meetings together. There's a pittance salary for several weeks (which does run out) while you try to hit the threshold to be considered a full time employee. There's also a few financial bonuses after you become a full time employee for sticking around. However, the job is basically cold calling and commission only.
Advice to Management
Every financial professional under 30 that was at my branch left around the year mark. There needs either be a salary or a stronger team alignment program. The big brokerages offer a base salary for 2 years.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Every financial professional under 30 that was at my branch left around the year mark. There needs either be a salary or a stronger team alignment program. The big brokerages offer a base salary for 2 years.

review_title: A Joke Of A Place To Work
pros: Good employee benefits and work from home opportunities.
cons:
Prudential is a joke of a company. I worked in the Newark corporate offices for many years. It is one big, inefficient bureaucracy. I once spent 18 months spinning wheels on a project with 15 other associates. In that time we were forced to create lengthy power point presentations that said nothing. Our final results were nothing more than a list of a few ways Prudential could hire people. Ridiculous. After years in this environment, you realize it isn't fixable and not worth your time and effort. I quickly learned that I could get away with not working while being paid a very high salary. I would show up at meetings here and there but spent hours each day at the gym next door, working out with many other Prudential employees doing the same. Also worked from home often where I caught up on home chores. Lastly there are many employees there who do not know how to keep their hands to themselves and eyes where they belong. Numerous times I had associates touch my hair, shoulders and arms and stare at my crotch.
Advice to Management
Work on reducing the bureaucracy and downsize high level people who create busy work for associates, and who are nothing more than an impediment to people trying to do real work.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Work on reducing the bureaucracy and downsize high level people who create busy work for associates, and who are nothing more than an impediment to people trying to do real work.

review_title: Important to find the right manager/management/function
pros:
Career Options
Diverse Product Lines
Total Compensation
cons:
Lack of Diversity of Thought Leadership
Inattention to organization deficiencies/Pretentious
Geographically (Newark, NJ) - Centric vision
Advice to Management
Prudential provides lip service to diversity, but does not truly embrace it, and leverage it to better itself. Thought leadership at the organization appears uniform from upper/senior management. A better job should be done communicating across and within product lines. A better job should be done to consider long term health over short term stock gains. Prudential is huge - talent is an average cross section with the Financial Services industry...not better. Recognize that. Hold management at all levels accountable (there is a complete lack of this today). There are far too many employees in jobs that aren't worthy of their job grade, especially at the Manager level and up.

review_title: Great company and lots of opportunities to grow!
pros: Prudential is the right company for anyone who likes structure, processes, development and growth. If you are a strong and talented performer, you will shine and will be rewarded more than adequately. It is a hierarchical organization with many layers, which translates into opportunities to grow. The company has great values and great ethics, exactly what you want in a Financial organization. And, the company cares and fosters diversity in all senses.
cons:
Change is not easy to implement at Prudential. It's OK if you have lots of great innovative ideas, just know that the process to get them to the light will not be an easy one. I still consider it worth it, but just know it's very different from a 'Google' type of culture.

review_title: Good job to put on a resume, don't expect to move up.
pros:
The company trains you and provides the equipment to work remotely. 
Pay is not bad and overtime can be an option.
cons:
Poor management
Micromanaging, office politics
Challenging job with little support for CSAs
Advice to Management
If you want your employees to perform well, you need to treat them like people. Not like corporate robots. The company literally hands out a book that has a section on Empathy. And management can't even practice that with their own workers. There are other companies out there who will pay you to do the same job, as much if not more money, and will treat you like a human being. Also, you will be hired onto a staffing agency and guaranteed benefits, and opportunities for growth within the company. DO NOT TRUST THIS. Their turnover is high because they do not hire people on or allow them to move up anymore. Since the pandemic the company has gone down hill. If you want to learn the job, take it for the training and then start searching at a new company once you've learned the tasks. Save yourself the headache.

review_title: Not the greatest, but not the worst
pros: Pay is usually in line or better. You can get exposed to many other projects. 401k is a good program. Educational opportunities are available. Managers are generally understanding if life events get in the way.
cons:
Middle and lower end management relies very heavily on upper management direction which can stifle creativity and major solution opportunities. The office politics create a CYA environment. Mobility is not impossible, but challenging. Health benefits are awful.
Advice to Management
Train your middle managers better. They need to work on team building and general supervision. Communication with those middle managers needs improvement.

review_title: Its not WHAT you know, Its WHO you know
pros: Decent pay, pension, 401K match, typical big/large company benefits (if you want to call them that)
cons:
Where do I even begin...?
The entire organization is pretty non-diverse and is filled with mediocre middle level and senior management( VPs and above) who have been with the company for decades and lack basic people management skills. Most of the leadership are in the manager roles not due to competency but only due to their tenure or their connections. The entire Marketing organization is filled with ex- CITI, AMEX and ETRADE folks who run an insurance company like a credit card business bringing in the toxic "dog-eat-dog" culture of unreasonable expectations, stifling innovation growth etc . The VPs hired from these companies in-turn bring their friends from previous work places, creating small tiny fiefdoms and promoting themselves. Pretty powerpoint presentations are the only output the organization really produces and acknowledges as outcomes. Innovation and growth are very hard to find anywhere and career growth is all depended on "WHO" you know and how many god-parents you have in the organization. Most VPs have an insane amount of ego and lack basic empathy, kindness or leadership qualities. Anyone with decent talent tends to leave the organization and there is decent amount of attrition of high performers.
Advice to Management
Dont hire individual contributors at VP level. Try and learn more about the people management skills before hiring. Remember, talent leaves organizations due to bad managers, not because of the company

I have been working at Prudential full-time for more than 3 years
Pros
There is something quite genuine about the company’s commitment to purpose and deep desire to be a better, stronger and more modern company.
Cons
The most senior leadership seem hopelessly lost. Restructuring happens constantly. Every senior leader seems to surround themselves with their own consulting firm. All the big names are here and then the big names are supplemented with boutiques. Leaders are out of touch, internally focused and lack courage. They hide behind culture and risk.
Advice to Management
If you truly want to save money, either save the Millions you are pouring into consultants or offset the senior leadership bonuses to cover the consulting expense. What a perfect way to guarantee a bonus... pay a ton for leaders who hire consultants to do the tough cultural stuff. Maybe leaders should have more courage or be willing to get their hands dirty. The senior folks need to stop believing their own PR. The chaos and swirl needs to stop.

review_title: Find a career that pays a base.
pros: Nice pension and benefits. Brand recognition. Some people genuinely want you to succeed but the red tape is thick and plentiful. Salaried employees, specifically the wholesalers, were very helpful and knowledgeable.
cons:
As a Fiduciary, you are pressured to sell core products (Pru issued), so, “best practices” is a conflict of interest. No training program. Zero support for experienced professionals. Cumbersome platforms. Way behind the time with technology and support. I can’t express the lack of training, you’re legit on your own. 
Experienced professionals will eventually become customer service reps without any steady stream of income due to lack of time to meet/close new biz. I’d recommend working at a bank.
Advice to Management
I was here 6.5 years and the turnover is brutal. I made it this long because I’m a workhorse. Found out the hard way the company will not promote within. Believe me, my production was there. 
Management promises the world, yet delivers motivational words, not results. Lots of orphans but the company limits who you call, example: no investment orphans, and you’d think those clients would need the most attention and be most interested in meeting. As a fiduciary, that was my thought. 
Simply put, find another company that invests in their employees vs charging you to work here (support fees after two years of working here kick in and it’s not cheap). Management level positions (manager of financial services) is a pyramid scheme. If you want a promo you need to recruit people on your own before you’re considered. Production isn’t a factor. Constantly interviewing/hiring heads to slow the bleeding of losing reps.
Helpful
Prudential Response
May 22, 2020 – Event Coordinator
Thanks for your feedback. As you know, a career in financial services can be difficult yet also rewarding

pros:
I've worked for several companies before Pru, and the experiences were never wholly positive. I was starting to wonder if it was even possible to be happy with your company, to be excited about work. Since joining Pru, I now know that it is—you just need to find the right company. So far, I've found that Pru has:

-Full flexibility (WFH)
-Unparalleled work/life balance
-Strong pay and bonuses
-Generous family leave
-A culture that emphasizes internal mobility
-A strong philanthropic culture that gives back to its communities
-Receptive and thoughtful leaders
-An extremely strong ethical philosophy overall

Yes, the company is undergoing a lot of changes, but that's de rigeur for the industry these days. It actually is creating a lot of opportunity internally, as the company explores new skill sets that it hasn't emphasized before. The company is in a great place for ambitious early career folks, or more mature professionals who want latitude to try new things.
cons:
It's a 140+ year-old company, and there are some legacy things still hanging around. There can be an over-emphasis on seniority, and there can be a lot of unspoken rules about how to approach or interact with senior leaders. The company also has a way to go in embracing technology. That said, the company understands these challenges and is doing everything it can to turn things around.
Advice to Management
You're on the right path. Onward!
Helpful (1)
Prudential Response
May 4, 2020 – Event Coordinator
Thank you for being part of a great team! Collaboration is one of our core values. We’re a growing, dynamic company that values and supports its talent
advice_to_mgmt: You're on the right path. Onward!

pros: Great benefits including pension, 401k, 15% discounted stock purchase plan.
cons:
Have to work 3 years to vest pension and 401k which is kind of a bummer. Overall, company is in a major shift. Recently did a Voluntary Separation Program which led to over 10% attrition. Lots of folks with institutional knowledge left but so did some dead weight which is good I guess. The politics between the various businesses have always held Prudential back. People are loyal to whatever business unit they work in rather than the firm as a whole. That goes all the way to the top. 

Promotions are very political especially in the Chief Marketing Office. People that have come from Citigroup for example promote their own buddies while rockstars who are not part of their click get left out.
Advice to Management
Get everyone to buy into the idea of one team one goal. Get rid of the culture of pinning businesses against each other. Remove people who abuse the promotions process by rewarding their friends and find the real gems to get even more productivity from them

advice_to_mgmt: Start communicating more specifics of the vision. Bigger, Bolder, Faster is a nice slogan, but there's never been anything specific provided to employees regarding what skills they need to meet your goals. Also, you better get the Customer Office under control and produce something with a revenue stream, instead of wasting company money and employees valuable time on all day town halls where presenters say nothing impactful. Not a fan of the new culture where mediocrity is valued so much.

pros: COWORKERS, some of my best friends and craziest experiences happened with some of the most hardworking & driven people that I have ever met. The company will support your growth heavily, if you make it to the top 10% of their earners and stick with them for 5+ years. I worked for the BEST, the #1 Prudential Advisors group- so also keep that in mind. Your experience will likely be even worse if you are not in Upstate, NY
cons:
The company gives you little to no support. You are your secretary, compliance officer, customer service associate, driver, marketer, office manager, and then you look for clients that you can make money off of with annuities and life insurance. Sometimes managed money...Warm leads, means cold calling with an excuse, they are "orphan" clients that do not have a current prudential advisor (that are dwlindling in number) that have often been called hundreds of times before you. If you happen to get ahold of one and set a meeting to review the clients life insurance, you then are trying to position yourself as their financial advisor. The clients typically already have a wealth management advisor, and the whole time working you are trying to find the next sale. There is NO SALARY. All sales chasing, commission only deals on product sales. The software Prudential uses is stuck in the 90s, it is horrible and salesforce is not built or utilizing extensions from the IT/Developers, that makes salesforce good. It is more of a way to document compliance (time consuming from your bottom line) & track which clients to contact next. The investment management software is so bad I couldn't handle it. Investment research/time to find a good portfolio or risk level for a client is just not possible with all the other tasks you have to do consistently to make ends meat. Americans no longer value life insurance besides some specific minority groups (Indian, Asian, etc)- look at the stats if you think this is racist or wrong. The entire demographic you target is middle-low income Americans who have no guidance, with roughly 200K-600K in retirement savings. Typically advisors scare them about bear markets, an inevitable crash, or running out of money into retirement, at which place they pitch an annuity & put majority of the clients liquidity at risk.

This is basically a glorified suit wearing car salesman for annuities and life insurance. Prudential will tell you that you are a business owner, when you are the FARTHEST thing from such. The company has made no initiatives to change or improve customer/advisor experiences on issues that matter. The Middle managers that you will report to, will tell you everything positive to keep you- THEIR SALARIES ARE DETERMINED BY HIRING. They are ball and chained to you staying, so just remember that incentive is not for your own good. The industry has a less than 25% 4 year retention rate, because of how horribly structured and set up for failure new advisors are, especially new graduates. Imagine being thrown in the water trying to get clients that are trusting you with their entire nest egg life savings, when you are 22 years old. Not likely going to happen. The only way to succeed as a youngster is to latch onto a senior advisor that is open to Joint Work, and has a big book of business that you can eventually overtake and work off of in the meantime.
If you want to become a financial advisor, understand that you are location STUCK. Building a book of business within prudential is the name of the game that typically takes 4-7 years to build to make $70K plus & when you want to move, you are back at square one starting from scratch.
Advice to Management
Read my cons, figure it out. You won't because the shareholders & bottom line profits are all that matters. 

Support your advisors with a base salary, a legit base salary, your company has a better credit rating than the US Government, with trillions under management- yet you pay your business owning advisors, a $0 base salary. Makes sense, makes great sense.

IF YOU ARE YOUNG OUT OF COLLEGE, do not accept this position like I did. It stunts your growth in finance & pigeon holes you in sales. You are not an investment analyst or a business owner I cannot stress that enough. The lies/over promises, under deliveries from management are borderline fraudulent. If I wore a wire to some of my managers 1 on 1s in my first 6 months, I would have a legit lawsuit on my hands. Promises of 6 figures, 75+ qualified client leads monthly, growing my business with multiple assistants I don't have to pay (you have to pay them from your sales commissions if you want them) & relationships they will setup with attorneys/CPAs for you- it was a never ending lie fest to keep me for their own hiring bonuses.

pros: There were few pros but not anymore
cons:
Silicon valley top management, especially the CTO operates like a mafia. Everything is controlled by this person, this level of narcissism is mind-blowing, and it trickles down. A bunch of people, usually her old friends and colleague are constantly brought in through the back door and its a continuum. People that are not part of this secret inner circle are constantly in the dark and have no idea what’s going on.

Every time interns are around there is pot luck. CTO and others behave like kids around them, it is agonizing to watch this coz normal times, this person doesn’t even get out of her cabin. I don’t think she has spoken to people sitting right in front of her cabin.

I have been living/working in the valley for a few years now, this place was a culture shock, so backward and so corrupt. A bunch of people calling themselves ‘architects’ still call shots from remote offices, and most of them are completely out of touch with the latest tools and trends. Name of the game here is ‘…just hang out and go home’.

New engineers are lured with the pretext of ‘stat up culture’. But the truth couldn’t be farther. There was an honest intention to run the silicon valley office like a startup. But constantly progressing wrong people including the CTO, has bread a culture of Narcissism and ‘yes men’ seeing a lot of growth.

There is no practical escalation in place, it exists in theory and it never works. If you are unhappy with someone, it is a gladiator fight with that person. Escalating yields noting, but still, the company’s code of conduct says ‘don’t confront’ if you have a problem, inform the manager. And the manager would never do anything. Old-timers know this very well and abuse this to the fullest.

Immigrants looking for career and immigration support, back off. Some folks here including HR are adept in abusing your time. These people don’t turn up like this overnight, they would have done this time and time again and perfected the art. Here’s how it goes, especially for green card EB2 has the following steps;

1. Prepping and Filing labor (4-6 months)
2. Labor approval (3-6 months)
3. Recruitment phase (within 6 months of labor approval) - where HR Fraud candidates
4. I140 filing and approval (4-8 months)
5. The rest of the process doesn’t matter since employer non-portability ends here.

In total, it takes 18-24 months to just apply for I140. 

HR and others in the organization know this very well. So what they do is, after step 3 (you would’ve already invested 10-15 months), you will be told that there are many strong candidates applying for that role so let's wait and see how it goes (this will be a blatant lie, no one would be interviewed). But after labor approval ie step 2, it is valid only for 6 months, if you don’t file i140 by then, you are back in line for step one and it will take 18 more months again. You are stuck with the company however messed up your director is, only people profiting with this whole deal are the HR, your director, and CTO, so they abuse it to the fullest. I have witnessed this.

Many people have been laid off, pods of contractors are let go, smart people have never been retained. I wouldn’t recommend this place to anyone.
Advice to Management
Change has to come from the top, and prudential Sunnyvale needs a serious overhaul at CTO level rest should all fall in place because normally it is one person that blocks all the goods and progress. If this person is replaced by someone honest and capable, everything should fall in place. This office has smart and hard-working individuals, narcissism bred by top management has tied them down.

review_title: Very solid employer, if not stable
pros:
The pay was competitive, the benefits were mostly excellent (except healthcare, being the now common high deductible tied to an HSA). Having good paid time off, able to sometimes work remote, an actual pension, stock purchasing, and a very good work-life balance is very nice. 

Nearly all senior executives are excellent, smart, open, caring people, and I worked directly with several. There are many great people who care about clients, especially in sales, client relations, even claims.
cons:
Heavily bloated middle management, with many people who create their own work and covet what they have to stay relevant and employed, many of them Peter Principle incompetent. 

Company restructures every 2 years or so, which creates anxiety, curbs productivity. Ageism likely a factor. If you are over about 50 and not a performer in sales or an exec, you are a prime candidate to be purged in one of these restructures. 

Serious concerns about this company's future. They will be around for another 100 years, they will survive, but disruption due to technological advancements (e.g. someone under 40 more interested in using an app based on algorithms than having any connection at all to a big company like Pru) will hit this company hard in book keeping, record keeping, client relations, even marketing jobs in the 2020's and beyond.
Advice to Management
Stop cutting good people who actually produce, and seriously look at just how boated your company is in the middle and ask yourself, look for yourself, at what your staff really does, what is really needed.

cons:
As with most large companies, your experience is dependent on your immediate supervisor and HR is there to protect company and not resolve employee issues.
New CEO and CIO have led to much uncertainty in direction of the workforce.

review_title: Good for Financial Advisor experience and that’s it
pros:
-Strong Life Insurance and Annuity products, maybe the best in the industry
-Great training program
-Unlimited PTO and freedom to set own time
-Bonus structure is very generous when starting out
-Able to be comprehensive with clients (take that with a grain of salt however)
-Good for starting a Financial Services career if you get the right local management.
cons:
-COMAND Investment platform is better off not existing
-Weak wealth management programs; fees are not competitive with the industry (meaning they are too high) and trading capabilities are minimal
-Senior Home Office Management is terrible (high turnover, and make huge lateral business model shifts every 6 months)
-Salaried Home Office employees are lazy and unhelpful
-Unnecessarily heavy administration on transactions can often delay you getting paid for them
-Direct reports to many superiors despite them saying it’s your own business
-Very behind on technology
-Marketing support is non-existent (though this could depend on local management)
Advice to Management
Find your identity as a company and stop shifting the business model every few months. This makes it seem like the company is in complete chaos. Also, you need to do a complete rebuild of the investment platform, not very slowly improve an already broken one.

Helpfu

pros:
Good benefits
Job security
Some groups are highly rewarding to work for
cons:
Depending on the group, Bureaucracy
Lack of incentives
Advice to Management
There really are dozens of different “Prudential’s”. It’s not a bad place to work as an insurance agent. What people don’t realize is how big the asset management business is, which is huge (#10 in the world). That’s a very good place to work for. However the law department is mind-numbingly, soul-crushingly bureaucratic. Senior management within the law department may be good lawyers, but they’re horrible managers, and they’ve run amok. There is absolutely zero incentive to do anything other than the bare minimum (“everyone is a ‘3’” is the mantra of the law department’s HR group - on a scale of 1-5). Decisions are largely form over substance, with a top-down management style that stifles any kind of dissenting, constructive feedback under the guise of not being a team player. At a recent law conference, they announced cutbacks, and when asked how we were coordinating these efforts with our business “partners”, a member of senior management responded that “we know better than they do what they need”.

Um, no, you don’t. 

If you’re thinking of working at Pru, take a look at the group you’ll be working for. They vary greatly. As for advice to management, Charlie or someone senior really needs to get involved in what’s going on in the law department, take a look at the EQ results and ask senior management what they’re doing about it. For the last dozen or so EQ surveys senior management’s response has been the same: tell mid level managers to tell their staff why they should feel lucky to work here, rather than having any kind of self-reflection to see that they are the problem, and that the solution needs to come from them, as well.
Helpful (3)
Prudential Response

pros: Nice facilities, good benefits, decent work/life balance, pay usually above market.
cons:
Constant reorganization, little opportunity for advancement for those below VP level. Month after month, year after year, I watched talented, hard working colleagues have their jobs eliminated, often being encouraged to reapply for lesser jobs in the name of “organizational optimization.” Managers (VP level and above) are usually insulated from this, and are able to use layoffs to cover for their own strategic failures.
Advice to Management
If you’re a VP, you have to be extremely incompetent to ever be held accountable for failure — or you have to be dumb enough to call out the toxic, highly politicized, backstabbing “Pru Polite” culture to become a target yourself. If you’re a merely mediocre VP who can tow the line, you’re in for a long and fruitful career at Prudential.

review_title: RUN AWAY if you want any life outside work
pros: Remote work option. Good retirement options
cons:
Terrible processes resulting in multiple steps to complete tasks causing need for excessive OT. No life. Feel like a slave. Terrible training program. Mass favoritism for promotions. Feel good projects unrelated to your job forced down your throat required for your performance reviews. Complete lack of concern for employees health or work life balance, especially salaried employees. salary not the level of other companies for same position especially with excessive OT required because of "PRU" excessive processes. End up working your life away for almost minimum wage at higher level positions. Results in a constant revolving door of employees.
Advice to Management
Institute a regular training program that stops taking case managers with minimal experience off claims when we are already understaffed and carrying higher caseloads. This is absurd and provide no benefit. Especially when the people doing the training are relatively new to the job and training newer people to improperly process claims. Get rid of all extra processes that add no value and just create more unnecessary work driving OT. Stop overloading people with "extra feel good projects" that takes away from regular work time that results in having to work OT to complete your actual work so the company can brag about how great they are. Start caring about your employees having a life to reduce burnout . That's a good start

pros: None I can actually think about.
cons:
Lets start. 
*their managers, (MFS) as they call them, MUST have experience in the company: process, product knowledge, ethics. Mine didn’t have any of those. I wasted my time and money there. 
* they will offer you the heaven and stars. I think it is enough saying that I didn’t even received my compensation for the last 2 weeks that I worked there. Moreover, if you resign don’t expect your “express” commissions to be paid right away. They will pay those (if so happens) 14 weeks after the date you resigned. 
* they will make you to pay for everything! Including: the transfer of your licenses to the company and your finger prints for example. 
*they just don’t care.
Advice to Management
It is a great name to work for. However, put in the managers position people with strong ethics and people that know their role, leaders. 
And please do not scam your employees. If someone goes to work is to earn money, not to waste it.

pros: Mon-Fri work week. Office setting.
cons:
Management is all male and are known as the "Men's Club". As compared to other companies that require the same licenses, they incredibly underpay people and prey on Veterans and their spouses to fill these positions. I took a 55% pay cut because it is in the same field as my degree with a promise of quick promotion based on my years of management experience. Never happened. HR complaints about sexist behavior and sexual harassment in the work place were swept under the rug. Visiting officials noticed the behavior and would have "talks" with upper management, but nothing ever changed.

It is a call center but they refuse to call it that or advertise it as such. You will be a glorified call center rep required to obtain federal licenses when you could go down the street to Dish Network and make more money without needing the licenses.
Advice to Management
A good leader doesn't play favorites and cater to only one gender. You want quality employees who want a career who will remain loyal. review_title: Change is good...but not like this!
pros: As large corporations are concerned, Prudential ticks all the boxes related prestige and good reputation. Their work facilities are pleasant and comfortable and they offer decent pay and health benefits.
cons:
As large corporations are concerned, Prudential is typical (not in a good way), when it comes to career advancement, real inclusion and diversity across all organizational levels and hiring from within. Culturally, Prudential espouses "employee development" and "career advancement", but in reality does not demonstrate support of their employees when they try to accomplish this. Like most large companies, advancement is doled out to based on "who you know" and not necessarily "what you can offer". Over the last 12 months Prudential has changed (CEO) leadership and with that has come a slew of layoffs that most would agree could have been handled better.
Advice to Management
Begin to demonstrate real appreciation of your current talent pool in addition to external candidates. 
Take a holistic look at "inclusion and diversity" from the top down and make the unpopular decision for real change.
Helpful (4)
Prudential Response
July 8, 2019 – Event Coordinator
We value the feedback we receive here on Glassdoor. This information is valuable as we assess our processes and programs
advice_to_mgmt:
Begin to demonstrate real appreciation of your current talent pool in addition to external candidates. 
Take a holistic look at "inclusion and diversity" from the top down and make the unpopular decision for real change.

pros: You will get tough skin. Because job is commission and bonus only, you have to learn how to make the most of your time. There are plenty of people to call and set appointments, and many people to work jointly as everyone is the same boat. You can design your own schedule and be as independent as you want it to be. Better than a 1099 firm because you get real benefits and training is decent. In addition, Prudential's products are very competitive but you do have to actively market yourself.
cons:
No real structure unless you put yourself down to it, therefore it is easy to lose weeks because not enough appointments were set beforehand, thereby slowing down sales. Also a lot of people quit early on, so there's a lot of turnover. That means you have to be quick on your feet and constantly be reinventing your business, and be willing to field train reps that might leave. I think this is typical of a sales firm environment.

pros: Prudential offers great PTO and Benefits.
cons:
El Paso Prudential is not on the same level as Prudential (corporate). It's actually one of the worse places I've ever worked for. If El Paso Pru was anywhere near the same as the corporate offices, I'd have stayed but maybe it's an El Paso thing because Leadership doesn't seem to have any common sense and the majority of the employees are seeking employment elsewhere. Several years ago when I started, it seemed like it was a great company to work for but lately leadership seems more interested in showing-off for social media but has lost sight of their current employees. They claim there is so much room for growth but the fact is they are begging for work to come to El Paso. They also pride themselves with hiring ex-military and spouses but yet treat these employees from their WOS groups worse than 2nd class citizens, I'm surprised they all haven't left. Salaries are extremely low and their aren't any goals or clear expectations on how to grow or get a higher salary.
Advice to Management
You have smart, educated, mid-to-high level employees whom are adults...start treating them as such. Allow more flexibility, allow more growth. Start spending on your current employees and treating them better. Quit saying you're going through growing pains; Prudential has been around for over 140 years and El Paso Prudential has been here for 4 years. Realize the employees you have are your biggest marketers, show them growth, higher compensation and flexibility and they will let everyone know what a great place it could be.
Helpful (5)
Prudential Response
June 18, 2019 –
We regret that your time at Prudential was not what you expected. We are genuinely interested in learning more about what led you to form this opinion of the program and management. Please contact our Global Business Ethics & Integrity help line at 1-800-752-7024 or online at tnwgrc.com/Prudential

review_title: PGIM - Great place overall to start your career as an investor
pros:
Smart colleagues who are generally laid-back
Exposure to a lot of different aspects of the investment process within PGIM Fixed Income
Very friendly, almost family-like culture ( "pru nice" is the official policy).
If you are at the company for three years or more, the company offers a cash pension plan. 
Brand new facilities 
Nice gym
Senior staff tend to look out for junior staff and connect them with job opportunities at the end of the analyst program
Strong support for the CFA program
The company does a lot in support of the surrounding community.
The investment business, PGIM, is run as a bunch of small to mid-sized business units which leads to an almost entrepreneurial environment.
cons:
Performance feedback could be more constructive 
Training for research analysts could be a bit more in depth (within PGIM Fixed Income, other units such as Prudential Capital Group, have a lot more training)
Three year analyst program is up or out - you may like this or you may hate it.
Three year 401K match is difficult to obtain when you are in a three year analyst program.
Advice to Management
Take a little bit more control over how each business unit integrates its junior staff into the business.
Allow a one or two year 401K match for junior staff in a three year program.
Helpful
Prudential Response

review_title: There are better opportunities out there.
pros: If you want to be called a Financial Advisor but focus on selling life insurance and annuities, this is the place for you. They do offer leads but they are not what they are cracked up to be, and some of them you have to pay for. They do offer high commissions, but you have to earn a certain amount before they pay you at all. Probably the biggest pro is their reputation.
cons:
You will definitely be paying them before they pay you. They do not cover E&O insurance, you have to pay rent for desk space, you have to pay for certain leads, and they require you to be in the office for several of their pointless meetings. These expenses are not disclosed until the last minute (or sometimes not until after you have been hired on). They do not seem to have any strategy and their training is highly lacking. Outside of insurance products, the firms knowledge of investment products is highly lacking. My advise to the potential employee is look for a firm that is actually known as a financial advising firm and not an insurance company.
Advice to Management
Stop the bait and switch. Be upfront about your costs and what you actually do. Don't disguise yourself as a financial advising firm when you are actually just an insurance company that does financial advising on the side.
Helpful (4)
Prudential Response
March 29, 2019 –

review_title: Top notch, high quality Fortune 500 company to work for.
pros: The people are all really top notch, high quality professionals. A pleasure to work with, by and large. Prudential "walks the walk" when it comes to developing your self and advancing your career. Their is money, time and it is a management priority to let people take advantage of multiple training opportunities. The benefits are also first rate - excellent medical and dental coverage, and a cash balance pension plan, in addition to a 401-k plan. Overall, a very high quality company to work for. I strongly recommend it.
cons:
It can be a bit bureaucratic at times, due to its large size. But this is manageable. 
 And sometimes they can get caught up in trying to be all things to all people. But even this mildly negative aspect is really positive, because it shows that they are always moving forward and not content with where they are.
Advice to Management
Prioritize and focus on the most important deliverable goals. Give more positive feedback to your strong performers.

review_title: Great company to work with. Not an easy job but you're ultimately compensated exactly as you should be.
pros: Total flexibility. You control the hours you work. The type of people you work with. The type of work you do. Excellent benefits package. Open architecture platform. No need to show proprietary products can give clients whatever is best. That said Prudential manufactures industry leading financial products. Company has great reputation and based on my experience that won't ever change.
cons:
Depending on your leadership team you may not receive the best training. I received a lot of excellent training but I didn't like how management was always pushing a new flavor of the month marketing idea. There wasn't a lot of depth to marketing plans.
Advice to Management
Check in with the people you're managing. Ask them what kind of help and support they need instead of throwing random ideas out to see what sticks. Dont always be so top down with your approach. Try to focus more on the advisors in years two through five. Almost all of the turnover I saw at the company happened at this point in an advisors career.

review_title: Ha Ha Ha Only can happen in Group Insurance Underwriting
pros: Good Benefits such as stock buying
cons:
This place is just wrong. No life work balance, everyone is working all the time. When management states all hands on deck, it implies non management work even harder and management does not help with productivity. Management can since they use to be line underwriters but believe they are above "line" work. Moving up is not about hard work but about who can smooch up to Management. One person that was promoted to management is a direct friend of Management. They gave that person support as well as actually help that person do the work. The older Underwriters will not say anything as many are afraid they will lose their jobs and just keep low until they retire. Diversity is a joke. Diversity is a white "Female", if you ever work here, take a look and you will see their is no management diversity but maybe a token minority (race). They also have a revolving door with new college hires. Management will work their tails off providing them a workload of more experience Underwriters and expected to complete the work. Shady practice of having the "nonexempt" employees work pass their normal hours and paying them back with time off. They have to pay them with money. That is why so many new hires leave or are miserable. They are afraid to go to HR as college kids they do not know what retaliation can happen from Underwriting Management.
Advice to Management
Advice to Corporate Management - Talk to the Underwriters individually and you will know why this review was written.

review_title: Customer Office: Management is the challenge
pros:
* Recruiting is rigorous and well done. Most people in the organization are smart and motivated. They genuinely care about what they do and the people they work with. They value communication and sharing which is really important within a large organization.
*Office space is modern and teams are usually provided all the assets they need.
* Good opportunity for more junior people to gain experience
cons:
* Culture of extreme micromanagement at the leadership levels.
* Every decision is second-guessed by management - on projects, team structure, policies. The smallest details are often the subject of drawn out debates by committee.
* Large shifts in project direction regularly occur, especially at the late stages
* Constant reorganization of leadership and teams leads to confusion and lack of process
*Semi-regular layoffs keep the entire organization on edge 
* Work/Life balance is a challenge - hours are long and you're expected to keep constant contact via email no matter what time of day or night it is.
* Politics and personality conflicts between leadership within the different business units is highly visible
Advice to Management
* Trust the people you hire to do their jobs
* Seriously rethink senior leadership structure within the Customer Office - culture starts from the top
Helpful (3)
Prudential Response
January 24, 2019 –
We regret that your time at Prudential was not what you expected. We are genuinely interested in learning more about what led you to form this opinion of the program and management. Please contact our Global Business Ethics & Integrity help line at 1-800-752-7024 or online at tnwgrc.com/Prudential
advice_to_mgmt:

review_title: In GBTS it depends on the team
pros: The flexibility in working from home is a nice option for days when you just don't feel like going into the office. The benefits are also decent and some of the team members are awesome. Some of the projects can be interesting and rewarding if you can give them enough focus.
cons:
I was supporting a techbology that is usually managed by a team of 4-5 in similarly sized deployments with only one other person, and being paid about 25% below what Prudential lists as the lower end of market reference range for my level. The idea of expanding the staff was continually shot down even after pointing out impending burnout. I was on-call 24x7 getting paged overnight a couple times per week for months on end and got little support in managing the workload of dozens of projects. I had 4 different managers over about 2.5 years due to the team getting reorganized. Although the company does promote work-life balance at higher levels, in some areas this seems to be confused for letting people work from home whenever they want even without actually letting them unplug outside of business hours.
Advice to Management
Pay attention to and provide more support for employees who tell you the workload is burning them out. Make sure the infrastructure projects that free up time for the more interesting and wider benefiting projects can get appropriate priority. Lower the tolerance for people who are not qualified for their positions to free up slots for the teams who desperately need more people.
Helpful
Prudential Response
January 8, 2019 –

review_title: Good potential, but the program needs to have more oversite
pros: Easy to get into the program. Good overview of the industry.
cons:
No oversight for the training program. Very little guidance when it comes to getting licensed. The "sales" classes are not really about selling. Good luck getting people to return phone calls or follow up on questions you may have.
Advice to Management
Please look into your Financial Professional Associate training program to make sure it is what you want it to be. The initial interview was informative and, had what I was told would happen (ie. guidance, training, and follow up) it would have been an awesome opportunity. My "manager" basically bowed out half way through the program and I, and the rest of the people in our group, were handed off to others to try and salvage things. I was told that there were multiple class times to fit my work schedule...there weren't. I changed work schedule around to make it to the classes...which were pretty haphazard and disorganized. I called the trainer several times looking for guidance without luck. Finally, toward the end of the programs preset time...which magically changed from 13 to 26 weeks, I received a call from the recruiter who said that the "manager" stepped down and went back into production and the trainer lost all of his contacts in his telephone which is why he never returned my calls. My new "manager" called me to tell me that he was going on vacation for 2 weeks and we'd chat when he got back...which turned into another game of phone tag. I already have one of the licenses, so I plan on pursuing this further with another company. Please get some oversight going. You have a potentially awesome program...it just seems so disorganized and, for me, disappointed.
Helpful
Prudential Response
November 2, 2018 –
We are sorry to hear that your time at Prudential was not what you expected. We believe our CDP program is a valuable tool in developing individuals who will help our customers solve the financial challenges they face in today’s complex economy. Even though you are no longer employed with Prudential Advisors, we are interested in learning more about your experience. Please contact our Global Business Ethics & Integrity help line at 1-800-752-7024 or online at www.tnwinc.com/Prudential

review_title: ESCAPE WHILE YOU STILL HAVE YOUR DIGNITY
pros:
- You’ll get very good at cold calls, living on very little money, giving product presentations, and parking in tiny stalls

- More initial support for new hires than many other insurance sales companies
cons:
- They’ll tell you you’ll make $100k+ a year, but you find out later that less than 5% make it past the first four years. You’ll eat dirt for those four years before you can even afford instant noodles, let alone rent. Be prepared to have your gf walk out on you when you have to move back in with your parents 

- Home office turns a blind eye to sexual harassment if the perp makes them enough money; they’ll just give you the number for their internal therapist and tell you not to talk about it to save their reputation (they’ll also take about two months just to address your concern)

- Never seen a company this prominent be so disorganized. They will lose your client’s checks, put client monies into other clients’ accounts, lose forms, etc., and of course it ends up being your problem not theirs. Don’t bother complaining to upper management, they’ll just lose that too

- There isn’t much training beyond the initial phase. The only way to learn how to do your job is to give experienced agents a cut of your business.

- People don’t really know much about financial planning or their products, or anything really (yup, even the experienced agent that you just gave 50% of your parents 401k rollover to). They just tell you what the person above them told them to say

- You’ll soon learn that “Financial Advisor” is synonymous with “Salesperson without a college degree” and that the CFP was created by the insurance industry to justify selling life insurance. 

- They’ll promise you refunds for things such as classes, then change the rules after your requests were already approved. On that note, they’ll also “forget” to pay out bonuses such as recruiting bonuses, then tell you that you no longer qualify for them

- After a while you end up seeing people as dollar signs and forget social interaction is for anything other than selling them stuff they don’t really need. Your friends and family might stop answering your calls a few months in
Advice to Management
- Quit
Helpful (16)
Prudential Response

pros: The company is well managed at the top and very focused on developing talent and talent mobility. As a global financial services leader you will have opportunities to move among business lines to gain valuable experience if you request it. The company is also financially stable and will be around for a very long time because of how they approach their capital management and investments.
cons:
There's a culture that's called "Pru polite" meaning that, in general, people are averse to taking risks and 'shaking things up'. Also, the physical environment in many locations in the US still resemble an old, sterile insurance company. The company talks about digital transformation but does not yet have the internal capabilities, nor the fortitude, to truly become digitally agile in business areas that are badly in need of them.
Advice to Management
Invest in becoming more digitally agile so you're not late to the market with products and services that smaller, more nimble insurance companies are capitalizing on right now.

review_title: Good company hindered by bad (getting worse) culture
pros:
1.Work Life Balance
2.Good Benefits
3.Commuting hub
4.Decent salary (but you could do better in some cases)
cons:
1.A lot of cliques formed by long-term employees who gang up on individuals.
2.Lack of accountability-a lot of finger pointing at others when things go wrong.
3.People taking credit for the work of others to show their 'value' to the organization.
4.Feedback can be used in a way to demean and demoralize.
5. Very, very obvious lack of diversity and inclusion at VP levels.
Advice to Management
Disband cliques of employees who have been there for far too long. In many cases, 20+ years. They've become arrogant bullies. Those are the people who drive your good talent out of the door or cause lawsuits.

pros: They have really great benefits.

review_title: Middle Management Will Make or Break Your Experience
pros: Great benefits, brand name recognition, huge resources, SOME fantastic support staff, trying frantically to catch up on the tech front
cons:
All commissions on the FPA and FP side of the company, Middle management is incentivized to bring out the worst in themselves and their team. The office and team you end up with will decide whether you succeed or fail unless you have the experience necessary to navigate and steer clear of the New Org.
Advice to Management
Fire the dead weight and recognize the potential. Office managers will wreck the environment real quick and can be real cancerous, principle or not they should have the experience of doing the job first and make their overages based off of different metrics. Push the tech and the teams and offer a small base salary to start and you will have a strong, sustainable Advisor Divison.
Helpful (3)

review_title: An unfair company that has no problem throwing away valuable employees who work hard
pros: Benefits, hours and paid training
cons:
Swept under rug when it comes down to it
Advice to Management
Do not offer a position to someone, pay them to get trained and toss them if they’re struggling without even offering additional training or another position within the company that will better suit them. It doesn’t make sense to invest in an employee then not think twice about them when the company says so.. Especially if they’re a really great employee and receives constant recognition and feedback. It’s not fair to anyone and I know of multiple people that this has happened to. It’s a great company to work for overall but from personal experience of working very hard and being tossed away like the work put forth in your company didn’t matter, it’s a bitter feeling. At least assist employees with finding another position or allow them to apply and give them another chance! I’ve applied for a dozen positions since I’ve been tossed away and I’m qualified for every single one yet for some reason I’m not even being considered again.... HR and hiring department also needs to know this. Very disappointed and giving up. You lost a very valuable and dedicated employee.. I’ll be sharing my experience with all of my colleagues.
Helpful (4)
Prudential Response

pros:
-Ability to make $100k+ annually after you get a year or 2 experience. Realistically expect to actually make $40k-$70K your first year depending on how involved you are. 
-Flexible work schedule meaning you can come and go as you please, work as much or as little as you want* (See cons as well)
-Great incentives to do as best as you can such as trips and bonuses
-Others and willing to help you as much as possible and make sure you succeed* (See cons as well)
-Unlimited leads from past advisors who have left, leaving numerous accounts in limbo that have not been contacted in years, this means money making opportunity
-Reimbursement for upfront expenses
cons:
-Do not expect to take a day off your first year. If you do, expect to hear about it from your "managers"
-During pre-contract, you need to have 2 hours every Friday set aside for a conference call that is essentially just a waste of time talking about what you and everyone else did during the week and if you didn't meet their expectations, be ready to get hammered in front of everyone.
-Do NOT believe a recruiter if they tell you that you will make over $100k your first year. You do not have the product or market knowledge off the bat to make this. The only exception would be that you already have a year or two experience in the industry.
-Do not have a job while acquiring your licenses or else you will be hammered for not advancing fast enough.
-Trainers say they are there too help you during license studying, but they aren't, they just refer you too the material or company you are studying through
-Lot's of up front costs that you need to have saved for. My $800 that was told to me during an interview with my recruiter turned out to actually be $1800
Advice to Management
Recruiters, stop bringing in as many people as possible and start finding quality people. Consider starting a pre-FA training position that teaches to the test, the industry as well as the company. That type of organization will improve your turnover rate. Stop with the "only 11% make it" line. More would make it in the industry if there was a more organized approach to the company
Helpful (5)
Prudential Response

We are sorry to hear that your time at Prudential was not what you expected. pros: Great underwriting and products. You have friendly management and work with great people. The wholesalers are very knowledgeable and helpful. They give you free leads to help start you off. If your a good producer people are willing to help with some marketing expenses, such as seminars and etc..
cons:
For new inexperienced reps they only give you a max draw of 1200 a pay cycle. Which is not enough for any adult to survive on if they don’t live at home with their parents. I would only recommend this position to someone who is in college and living with their parents.
Advice to Management
Each new reps have different needs. You can’t expect someone who was a great producer in another company settle for a 30k draw. Some people need consistency and are willing to work hard if you put a little trust in them. Every adviser draw should be accesss differently based on production not on their experience. You will lose out on a lot of great advisor who actually love working for Prudential but can’t afford to stay. When you give a new rep the bare minumn draw they have no money for marketing, yet alone pay their bills.

review_title: If you don't want to make money for two years, this is the job for you.
pros:
*COMMISSION ONLY* Coming on as an experienced advisor having all my licenses I was under the impression I'd be handing many hot leads and marketing material to get a jump state on making great money. I left my job making $75K because they told me that I'd be making six figures my first year with my experience and how many ORPHAN account they have. In my first 3 months I have made $1500 and had to pay them $300 per month for office space and $500 for E&O insurance. So I basically broke even. I just left the company because the money just isnt there if you don't come on board with a book of business and people you know that will buy life insurance sorry but you're screwed plain and simple. They give you a bunch ORPHAN accounts that you can call but 90% they don't pick up, the number is bad or there is no email on file. Then they expect you to purchase Intellius.com to stalk the clients to find a good number. When you do get in touch with a client they expect you to get an appointment by telling the client they only have little time to convert their policy to a permanent policy even if the conversion doesn't come due in 5-10 years! You're going to have clients bail on you all the time drive your car all over your state and waste time! I'm sorry I wasted 3 months here and leaving my $75K job! At least I found something better and I never do write reviews but I had to get this out there so hopefully you won't make the mistake I made.

PROS: Good team that really wants you to succeed but have limited resources to do so.
-They pay and sponsor your licenses. You should get them and leave.
-Work on you own schedule
cons:
MANY MANY CONS!

-Commission ONLY
-Pay for office space and insurance
-Drive your car all over your state
-Only ORPHAN leads that are terrible
-Marketing is terrible
-You're basically cold calling
-Sell life insurance to people that already have life insurance.
-Going to clients homes (NASTY) Most clients are dirty people.
-If you don't mind cold calling all day and night over and over, then this job is for you.
-Very boring and dry place to work.. Not exciting at all.
Advice to Management
Base salary for the first 2 years would be a huge start.

Stop having the advisor pay for every little thing!

Utilize more marketing techniques so that new advisor can make money in the first month.

I gave the company and position a 2 STAR because the management really does want you to succeed but I'd say only about 5% of people could make a career out of this.

review_title: Used to recommend, but would no longer
pros: Offers flexible work arrangements including remote work and flex schedules. Most of the non-management employees are some of the greatest people I've ever worked with - however, frequent restructuring means many great people are let go often.
cons:
New "leadership" is more focused on the bottom line now more than ever, and I left feeling like nobody was really looking out for the customer. Performance reviews are based on who manages you - for six of the eight years I worked for the company, I received above average or exceptional reviews from various managers (I had quite a few due to restructuring which, as I mentioned, happened very frequently). But with my last manager change, I only received "average" reviews under the new manager, which affected my bonus compensation.
Advice to Management
Layoffs due to restructuring should be an absolute last resort but seems to be the norm. If you must reduce staff, be sure to act like leaders and treat eliminated employees respectfully.

pros: Lots of training on sales and leadership, access to the best products and carriers on the market
cons:
The hiring process is very misleading, recruiters don't outline all the risks associated with this career. Like I depleted all my savings completely, emptied all my credit cards and eventually stooped down to being completely broke and had to file for a bankruptcy after a year of working with Prudential, and this is not my personal issue because 9 out of 10 hires left the company within the first 3 months. And although Prudential keeps praising itself nonstop (they are very proud of their "ethical" culture and great team) but in fact it turns into a nightmare for non experienced advisors who struggle to survive. Actually they got sued for that approach in multiple class action lawsuits, which I've been a part of, so be prepared for blatant lie!!! Over the course of my employment I signed up almost all my friends and family members for their services and products (the same happened to the majority of my coworkers) and most likely these people'll remain the clients of the company because of the famous name of the brand Prudential. So it's a very smart business model when they don't really care about huge turn over and personnel retention because every new hire brings new piece of business to the company and Prudential doesn't invest much in their advisors compared to the stream of income they bring to the firm.
Advice to Management
Try to value the people rather than just care for the production, when you're talking about "support" for advisors come up with some sort of base salary, which will allow new advisors to get onboard and learn the craft rather than just waste their time talking on different topics during never ending unpaid call sessions, seminars, meetings etc.
Helpful (7)
Prudential Response
January 23, 2018 –
As you know, a career in financial services can be very challenging yet also rewarding. We encourage all of our associates to share their challenges in order to address them. We are also interested in learning more about the concerns you shared. Please contact our Global Business Ethics & Integrity help line at 1-800-752-7024 or online at www.tnwinc.com/Prudential

pros: It was a great experience to have straight out of college. The title was a fancy way to say, back office operations. If operations and reporting is where you see yourself, then this is the job for you. Prudential is split into groups, and each group has several teams. It gives you the opportunity to rotate throughout your group, and learn all the different roles.
cons:
I was taught that it is good to get your foot in the door with a big company to gain some experience and than more internally for the job that you want. I realized quickly that it is difficult regardless if you're looking internally or applying out to different opportunities. Although there are several groups and teams, you are stuck within the operations group, just getting a different learning experiences with each role. So if you're someone who learns early on, that operations is not for you - it is very difficult to transfer to a different group.
Advice to Management
Understand your employees interests. I started my career in operations, but found that I had a real interest in systems and technology. If management paid better attention, they would see that they could use this interest, and combine it with the knowledge I've gained, and help create better processes for the group. Instead, they did not offer anything besides operations and forced me to look for new opportunities outside Prudential.
Helpful (2)

cons:
Prudential Advisors represent everything wrong with the financial services industry today. If you’re looking to get started in wealth management or financial planning this place should be your last resort. The job function of advisors at this firm is just to sell as many Pru life insurance policies as possible, which is why they require advisors to obtain the series 6 instead of the series 7. The entire business model creates conflicts of interest as you are incentivized to sell products rather than give sound advice. I spent my first year of employment there and did not see one single advisor write a financial plan, all of the revenue was generated by insurance/annuities and since the job is 100% commission the only way agents get paid is selling products. Their investment advisory platform was not competitive at all which made getting wealthy clients impossible. The result is that the most significant portion of recurring revenue comes from agents writing car insurance so essentially the company is giving the title of financial advisor to insurance salesmen.

The initial training isn’t too terrible, but once you become full-time (which happens after selling 5 policies) you’re essentially on your own. Pru likes to boast about their on going training however what they call training is bringing in a few wholesalers to tell the agents that their new products are the best in the marketplace. You never really learn the financial planning process.

Employee turnover is discouraging as well. The industry as a whole has an issue with this but Pru takes it above and beyond. I asked for them to pay for my series 65, 7, and first course of the CFP and management responded by saying that since those licenses/designations aren’t required they would only offer reimbursement. So you essentially are paying out of pocket for a job that is paying you nothing. The firm also has no education requirement for their advisors other than the initial licensing, which is partly why they cannot attract and retain talent. 

Lastly the lead program is a travesty. One of the major selling points of the job was the fact that Pru would provide their advisors with leads. The leads that were given out were either 90 year old clients who don’t want to be bothered, or clients who want to cancel the policy but haven’t been able to get ahold of an agent for years (because the salesperson quit within a month of selling the policy). Building your book is completely on you and since most of the new reps who come in through the CDP program are new grads with a ton of student debt it’s virtually impossible to get started. As a result you will be forced to hound friends and family by offering them expensive products to try and start your business.
Advice to Management
Management will not heed any advice. All the managers at the Pru Office swear that nothing in financial services has changed, citing their own experience and success as examples, meanwhile they haven’t produced in years. So they’re advice to new reps is “smile and dial” and remember that “life pays the bills” meaning that in order to make a decent wage you better be selling high premium policies.

However in reality everything has changed. The DOL has really hindered how insurance firms conduct retirement business, financial technology is changing the way Advisors connect with clients and build solutions, and independent RIAs are starting to dominate the market share, capturing talented advisors and adopting the latest fintech to interact with clients. The days of cold calling and selling products are dying while planning and advice is coming to the forefront. The result is that large firms are going to have to decide what their goals are do they want to be in the business of managing wealth and financial planning, or do they want to build and sell their products? For Prudential it may make more sense to focus on selling their products through other channels.
Helpful (12)
Prudential Response
December 26, 2017 – Director, Talent Brand & Marketing
We are sorry to hear that your time at Prudential was not what you expected. We believe our CDP program is a valuable tool in developing individuals who will help our customers solve the financial challenges they face in today’s complex economy. Even though you are no longer employed with Prudential Advisors, we are interested in learning more about what led you to form this opinion of our program and the management staff. Please contact our Global Business Ethics & Integrity help line at 1-800-752-7024 or online at www.tnwinc.com/Prudential
advice_to_mgmt:
Management will not heed any advice. All the managers at the Pru Office swear that nothing in financial services has changed, citing their own experience and success as examples, meanwhile they haven’t produced in years. So they’re advice to new reps is “smile and dial” and remember that “life pays the bills” meaning that in order to make a decent wage you better be selling high premium policies.

However in reality everything has changed. The DOL has really hindered how insurance firms conduct retirement business, financial technology is changing the way Advisors connect with clients and build solutions, and independent RIAs are starting to dominate the market share, capturing talented advisors and adopting the latest fintech to interact with clients. The days of cold calling and selling products are dying while planning and advice is coming to the forefront. The result is that large firms are going to have to decide what their goals are do they want to be in the business of managing wealth and financial planning, or do they want to build and sell their products? For Prudential it may make more sense to focus on selling their products through other channels.

review_title: Awful Pay and misleading recruitment process
pros: You can put that your have financial advising experience with prudential and people will believe it as they are a somewhat respected company. In reality, the training is non-existent and no one has time for you.
cons:
They say you make your own schedule but they require you to be in the office for nine hours worth of meetings a week on top of the after hours they make you stay for. They say they have unaligned clients (clients whose advisors have left) which is true but those clients already have multiple policies and do not want to hear from you as they have already heard from other new employees. They expect you to call all of your friends and family multiple times over. It doesn’t matter if they say no. They will tell you that the company average for a first year employee is 70k but only one new Professional Associate ( 0-4 yr old prudential advisors) out of 30 make more than 70. The rest make 40 K and under. The retention rate during my year was 10%. Due to this, the office is dead. You can hear a pen drop in there. In other words, the office environment is awful. 

They will tell you that this is the same for most offices but I haven’t found this to be true. They only pay commission. And do not care how much you make after you get 5 clients because the managers don’t have to pay prudential a fee if you quit after that. If you are looking for a career opportunity where others genuinely care about you, invest in you, and foster growth this is not the place for you.

Hard work, but they will put in equal amounts of hard work into you.

cons:
Pay is commission only. While they put money into a "pool" to make sure you get paychecks over a period of time, it is all dependent on actual production, with no base salary. Not necessarily a con, but not for everyone.
Again, not necessarily a con, but at least at the beginning, requires more than a typical 9-5 schedule. Make your own schedule, which has its benefits, but must be structured, and often requires work into the evenings as you work to build up your book of business (though not necessarily required).

review_title: Company has no ethics or loyalty
pros: Retiree health benefits and stock options
cons:
This review is for group insurance located in Roseland, NJ. They have been laying off and firing employees age 50+. Management would give a review but will provide negative comments to put you on probation and then fire you and will not change the comment even if it is proven false. The review is the company's documentation and it will be your word against their word. Believe this ADEA violation, but they throw in someone that is under 40 so that it will not be called age discrimination. Those employees that are removed have been in the company a long time and have greater knowledge than the college hire replacements. This all has to do with the bottom line as they have high expenses and need to trim expenses by end of 2017. They make employees work longer hours so that they can hire fewer employees and inexperience employees. Company states great work/life balance. Not the case as employees are working 10-12 hours a day and on weekends. Management expects the employees to complete all the work by unreasonable deadlines. However, no management is working late which causes employees be disgruntled. (If management expects employees to work late at night, set an example and do the same thing.) Beware that there is no promotions. If you work hard you will still have to post for the higher level job if it comes available. Also, non exempt employees (college grads) are working more than 40+ hours per week should be paid time and a half. based on Fair Labor Standard Act. Instead, management will give non exempt employees straight comp time and no overtime pay. Also, notice their are less minorities in Roseland. If you are a minority, it doesn't seem that you will last too long.
Advice to Management
Senior management needs to listen to the front line employees and not management as they distort information in order to cover up faults and incompetence.
Helpful (10)
Prudential Response
August 22, 2017 – Director, Talent Brand & Marketing
We appreciate you sharing your feedback. Prudential is committed to doing business the right way, treating its employees fairly and complying with all of our legal obligations. We take all allegations of discriminatory conduct and unlawful behavior seriously and would like to get more details from you so that we can conduct a comprehensive investigation and take appropriate actions. 
 
Please let us know if you are willing to provide more information by contacting: (1) Human Resources, (2) your Business Ethics Officer, (3) Global Business Ethics & Integrity: www.tnwinc.com/Prudential or 1-800-752-7024, (4) any member of management, and/or (5) the Law Department. You can raise your concerns without fear. Prudential will not engage in, nor tolerate retaliatory, threatening or harassing acts against any employee who, in good faith, reports suspected unethical or illegal behaviors or practices.
